story: The groups said in a press release that they ‘understand the indignation’, but that it ‘cannot be used as an excuse to exploit our fight to make simplistic analyses’.‘Focusing on just one case who suffer or who have suffered from aggression need our solidarity, and no assault, be it of high or low intensity, can be justified.’Other protests have been organized to share anti-bullfighting sentiments.Aida Gasc, director of AnimaNaturals in Spain, told Euronews: ‘All the bulls that participate in the morning in the runs are driven directly in the afternoon to the bullring where they’ll title: Swedens WAGS stay hotel ENGLAND team
story: Swedish WAGs like Maja Nilsen (pictured) wife of Man Utd's Victor Lindelof are staying at the Renaissance with the England teamEngland's players will be staying in the same hotel as the Swedish WAGs ahead of tomorrow's World Cup quarter final, MailOnline can reveal.Harry Kane and his teammates will sleep in the 196-room Renaissance in Samara where Sweden's wives and girlfriends will also be staying.But the Swedes are bragging they already have the edge after they were booked into Samara's only five-star resort - leaving England in a more modest four-star hotel. Sweden's FA President Karl-Erik Nilsson joked: 'You could say Sweden is one-zero up already.'  His countrymen are in the Lotte Hotel, which opened in April, and is the best hotel in the area.   The hotel's sumptuous  fine food menu lists the amount of calories contained in each item for weight watchers - which even has its own caviar menu where a spoonful of Stugeon is available for £71 and a lesser 'Pike' variety for £16.Their players can also tuck into tuna with chukka seaweed salad, crab cake with tomato salsa, roast duck, creme of pumpkin soup with Kamchatka crab and cream cheese and tiger shrimp and scallop brochettes and a filet Mignion steak.          Harry Kane and his teammates will sleep in the 196-room Renaissance (pictured) in Samara where Sweden's wives and girlfriends will also be staying          England has been allocated the four-star Renaissance (foyer pictured) Hotel in Samara while their World Cup quarter final opponents are staying at the town's only five star resort           Sweden are crowing to have been allocated better accommodation than their rivals. Their FA President Karl-Erik Nilsson (left) joked: 'You could say Sweden is one-zero up already.'Rebekah Vardy reveals the England sex ban has been lifted...Share this articleThe country's FA general secretary Hakan Sjostrand chuckled: 'Yes we also have caviar on the menu, but that will be OK as long as England have their fish and chips.' Meanwhile Gareth Southgate's men will be staying on the outskirts next door to an Ibis hotel with a McDonalds nearby and traffic streaming outside and fridge magnets are on sale in the foyer for  £1.50. The Renaissance offers a range of salads, soups, grilled meat and fish in its 'Terrace' restaurant with its most pricey item being a grilled steak for £22.           England boss Gareth Southgate had no say in the hotel, which was chosen by FIFAHowever, England's players rarely eat in hotel restaurants and have their own food prepared for them by an official FA chef.The 196-room Renaissance was opened in 2003 with rates starting at £70 a night compared to the more expensive Lotte where the cheapest rooms are £200. But the standard of cotton sheets and the fine food will be forgotten once the teams do battle for a place in the World Cup semi-finals.Mr Nilsson, who was wearing his country's football short and is a Wolverhampton Wanderers fan, said: ' FIFA chose this hotel. So it is one-zero for us then.'We do have caviar, but I am pretty sure they can manage without caviar and it will be a good game. Otherwise they are welcome to visit us. It will be a fantastic match between two great teams.'He added: 'We had Netherlands and France in our (qualifying) group and we beat Italy in a play off. We beat Portugal last year in a friendly.          The Swedes are in the Lotte Hotel (pictured), which opened in April, and is the best hotel in the area where the cheapest rooms available at the moment are £200 per night          The Lotte's sumptuous fine food on offer even has its own caviar menu where a spoonful of Stugeon is available for £71 and a lesser 'Pike' variety for £16'And we won the group of four here which had Germany in it and we have just beaten Switzerland in Russia who are ranked sixth in the world…why shouldn't we be confident?'We also have the biggest respect for our opponents. But we go in to the quarter final in a very good mood.'  The Swedish delegation have been privately meeting human and civil rights leaders in Russia and supporting their work. Mr Sjostrand added: ' England have so many good players and they should beat us. But it would be so boring if life was always like that.'He said the Swedish fans would support England if Sweden is knocked out and added: 'Harry Kane is a fantastic player and we follow the Premier League in Sweden.    Despite Sweden claiming victory in the battle of the hotels, Gareth Southgate's men will be hoping for a repeat of their heroics when they beat Colombia on Tuesday (pictured)'I am a Manchester United supporter and one of my daughters is called Ester because of Manchester.' I also follow Ashley Young , Rashford and Lingard. England have so many good players.He said he expected between 1000 and1500 fans to be in the Samara Arena on Saturday evening to be supporting Sweden.He added 'To come here is a challenge because of a lack of flights and it is really expensive.'We had 500-6000 people at our last match because it was in St Petersburg and it not so difficult to travel from Sweden. People came by car and by train through Finland.'We hope for a great match and of course a Swedish victory. But overall, a fair match which will be great for the supporters and enjoyed by the world.'

title: How Jesse Lingard Englands King Social Media
story: This tweet by Jesse Lingard this week assured his place as the king of social media in the England team, whose image has been transformed by players' use of Instagram and Twitter          He is now turning his footballing and online prowess into a strong brand, based on his distinctive goal celebration, in which he spells out his initials with his hands          He is now busy building a brand around his celebration and his nickname 'JLingz'The public's love of the England team is a million miles from when Sam Allardyce lost his job as England manager  after he was filmed talking to undercover reporters posing as businessmen.Back then, confidence in the national team was at rock bottom.  But now, just two years on, England have rebuilt their public image, thanks to squeaky-clean Gareth Southgate and his squad of fresh-faced young players.Among them is 25-year-old Lingard, who, with four million Instagram followers, is at the head of a group of stars whose social media posts are watched by thousands of young fans.EXCLUSIVE: Sweden's WAGS will stay at the same hotel as the...EXCLUSIVE: Man dumped by Gareth Southgate's wife for England...Share this articleA social media hit this week came Jesse filmed fellow young player Trent Alexander-Arnold saying 'It's coming home' to him on the pitch after the Colombia victory.Lingard has also posted videos of himself dancing in his pants with Ruben Loftus-Cheek in the changing room, being shaved by teammates and celebrating with fans.Such videos give fans a players' eye view of the World Cup and take supporters inside the England camp in a way never seen before.     He is currently believed to be single after his relationship with Jena Frumes ended in scandal          Jena split from Jesse before tweeting: 'At least I can say I tried plus enjoyed the ride'          Lingard and Ms Frumes split up in March after she posed for steamy pictures in his shirtSocial media experts say his and other players' tweets and videos are building a new image for the national side, totally distinct from the days of 'dentist chair' drinkathons and Graham Taylor's 'turnips'.Former Twitter head of sport Lewis Wiltshire told The Daily Star: 'If there is a player who uses Instagram better or more effectively than Jesse Lingard, I'm yet to see them.'These players are from a generation where they understand and enjoy this stuff.'I'm convinced it's at the heart of why this England team's public image is different from, say, 10 years ago.'Mr Wiltshire says he doesn't believe a representative handles Jesse's social media for him, as with other players, which may be part of its success.The Manchester United midfielder could now use his performances in the World Cup to launch a strong Beckham-like 'brand'.He has used Instagram to give fans a players-eye view of the World Cup, including video of him dancing in his pants in the changing room  He stays close to his grandmother and grandfather, who helped get him into football as a childThree weeks before the tournament, Lingard applied for four trademarks, three centred on his nickname 'JLingz' and another featuring his goal celebration, in which he holds his hands in front of his face and spells out his initials.He has since launched a clothing range, including caps, T-shirts and hoodies emblazoned with his goal celebration logo, which have already all sold out on his website jlingz.com.Andy Sutherden, head of sport  marketing at H+K Strategies, told CityAM: 'Jesse Lingard's team has acknowledged the fact that if he does well in Russia, there’s an immediate opportunity but one with a very short shelf life. 'They’re also understanding of the fact that people who become known for something different - think Crouch and the robot - extend their marketing appeal beyond the audience of sport.' Meanwhile, there are rumours that Manchester United bosses are set to increase his wages from £75,000 to £150,000 to keep other clubs from trying to tempt him away.          The 25-year-old midfielder is one of a new generation of players who is savvy with social media          While communicating with his millions of Instagram followers, he has created a strong brand          He has now used the platform to launch a range of clothing, including these JLingz capsOne thing that makes his social media postings different from some of teammates is the lack of a girlfriend.He dated childhood sweetheart Emma Hyde for five years until he ended it in 2016.He later went out with glamorous US-based Instagram model Jena Frumes, but she dumped him after a tabloid newspaper revealed he had sex with an admin assistant from Sheffield in a hot tub.Jesse remains committed to his family, and even has a picture of his mother Kirsty, 49, in his room in Russia.As a boy he attended Beamont Community Primary school in Warrington, where most of the boys his age wanted to play rugby league.His grandfather Ken, a former GB power lifter, was the one who suggested he take up football and ferried him to training sessions and matches.    Before the World Cup, he made his nickname and goal celebration logo trademarks          Lingard's recently-released clothing range has already completely sold out on his websiteWorld Cup 2018: England's Jesse Lingard has trademarked his JLingz celebration — and he's done so at the perfect time | City A.M.

title: Lewis Hamilton says pet bulldog Roscoe earns 530 day model Los Angeles
story: Lewis Hamilton poses with his dog Roscoe. Hamilton might be the breadwinner but Roscoe brings home £560 per day as a model'He gets paid, $700 dollars a day, it's ridiculous and he gets his treat, he loves it.'Roscoe is so important to the F1 legend he has had his sperm frozen so after retirement he can use a breeder to get more puppies.          Roscoe enjoying the sunshine as he gets used to life in Los Angeles where he works as a model          Roscoe had to be snipped because he was ejaculating in his sleep. However, Hamilton had his sperm frozen Hound of the Brigade: Sherlock the forensic fire dog can...Share this articleThe bulldog cannot breed naturally after getting the snip after 'complications'. Roscoe had to be taken to the vet because he accidentally ejaculated in his sleep.Speaking to F1's 'Beyond The Grid' podcast, Hamilton said: 'The reason I had to get him snipped, is because, the poor guy would wake up randomly and he would ejaculate everywhere. He would get scared and wouldn't know what happened, it was so funny, but it was bad as it was everywhere.          'Sitting in on engineering with dad today' Lewis Hamilton's dog gets the inside scoop at his meetings           Roscoe on the beach! The bulldog travels around the world with Lewis Hamilton the F1 star           When in Rome: Roscoe poses in front of the Colosseum in Rome on yet another holiday           Roscoe and Coco cuddle up to their dog sitter in Los Angeles while Hamilton is away           Roscoe poses in the sunshine with a friend. The dog has a modelling career earning him thousands of dollars           Lewis Hamilton and dog Roscoe hanging out with friend Daniel Forrest, known as Spinz Beats in the USA'So he had to get the snip, but I can't not breed this boy, he is so handsome and has the kindest heart. At some stage we will get some puppies, so probably once when I retire from racing and have a family, I am definitely getting more Roscoes.'Hamilton who made a name for himself by racing past his competitors on the circuit is believed to be worth just shy of £200m.The now renowned Formula One star recently placed third at the 2018 Monaco Grand Prix. Though he fell just short of victory, his other accomplishments after more than a decade as a professional Formula One racer speak for themselves.          On the road again! Roscoe has 142,000 followers on Isntagram and makes money as a model           Bulldog Roscoe is often featured on Hamilton's social media. This post was captioned: 'Roscoe has the purest of hearts. A dogs love is second to none. Unconditional and unwavering'He is preparing for Silverstone, after he lost his championship lead to Sebastian Vettel in Austria. Hamilton is the highest-paid professional athlete in the United Kingdom. In 2012, he Mercedes's racing team in a staggering $100 million (£195.5 million) deal, making him one of Formula One's highest-paid drivers of all time.

title: Wilander backing Edmund upset Djokovic
story: Kyle Edmund won the first set against Novak Djokovic in his third round Wimbledon clash, starting minutes after England won a place in the World Cup semi finals          The Yorkshire player won the first set against three-time champion Novak Djokovic but eventually lost in four sets Those who had tickets for Saturday's tennis were issued with pink and blue re-entry wristbands so they could run back inside once the football action was over. Before the England match started there were chants of 'get the tennis off' as fans waited eagerly for the football to be put on the big screens.Clive McCabe, from Twickenham, had seats on Court One but left to watch the football when the Three Lions' match in Samara kicked off at 3pm British time. 'It's the most people who have left Wimbledon on middle Saturday between 1pm and 2pm. There's more people leaving than going in,' he said. Three Lions ROAR! England fans turn the streets of Samara...Up to 10,000 tickets go unsold for the England vs Sweden...Share this articleBefore that, fans could be seen knocking back pints and basking in the gorgeous sunshine as they got ready to cheer on Edmund, the last remaining British singles player at Wimbledon.Sir Bobby Charlton was also spotted signing autographs and joining in on the fun. He was joined by sporting stars including Sir Mo Farah, boxer David Haye, Dame Jessica Ennis-Hill and former cricketer Andrew Strauss, on another scorching day at Wimbledon.The All England Lawn Tennis Club (AELTC) announced on Friday that Edmund will play third on Centre Court, with the scheduling likely to avoid a clash between the tennis and football.Haye admitted he would be one of those trying to juggle the two sporting events.            Scores of fans left Wimbledon this afternoon in order to make it to a pub in time to watch England play against Sweden          This fan was streaming the England vs Sweden World Cup quarter final while sat at Centre Court to watch Rafael Nadal           Fans left the tennis to go and watch the football in the nearby Rose and Crown pub in Wimbledon village          One fan said more people were leaving the tennis than arriving ahead of England's World Cup quarter-final            Some fans were clearly more concerned with the football than the tennis and could be seen watching on their phones          Another fan proudly showed how they were streaming the World Cup quarter final on their phone rather than pay attention to what was happening on the court          This fan could be seen paying absolutely no attention to the tennis as he watched the World Cup match on his tablet on court number one          Even the legends and officials seemed to be getting involved as Rod Laver, Billy Jean King and Phillip Brook, AELTC Chairman, all appeared to be distracted          Sweden fans at Wimbledon look disappointed as they check the score and realise that their team are losing to England          An England fan screams in joy at Wimbledon as she hears Southgate's side had scored against Sweden in the World Cup          Hundreds of fans piled on to Henman Hill as they waited for Kyle Edmund to face three-time champion Novak Djokovic          Although the fans had come to watch the tennis, they could be seen unfurling England flags and wearing replica shirts          As fans flocked to watch the tennis, many were dressed in England football shirts ahead of the big World Cup tie on Saturday'I'll try, I dunno how,' he told the Press Association. 'We're going to do it, we're going to do it.'Tennis star Heather Watson, who is not due to play on Saturday, also appeared preoccupied by the football.She tweeted on Saturday: 'FOOTBALL IS COMING HOME.' However Sir Cliff Richard, a regular at Wimbledon, said he would not be focusing on England's quarter-final.'I'm watching tennis. I'm here for tennis,' he said as he arrived. 'I'll get the results later. I hope they do well.'    Edmund headed to Centre Court with his coach Fredrik Rosengren urging him to enjoy the moment in what is sure to be a difficult match.Edmund was spotted with an England flag yesterday, as he threw his support behind the England football team ahead of their crunch World Cup contest.And there may be some ision in the Edmund camp with Fredrik Rosengren being Swedish.  Olympic gold medal boxer Nicola Adams, who was also in the royal box, said: 'I'll be focusing on the tennis - and hopefully I'll get the updates later.'Asked if she had a message for Edmund and the England team, Adams said: 'Good luck, and I hope they do really well, they've done really good so far.'            British tennis number one Kyle Edmund, pictured, took the the time out to throw his support behind the England football team          It is set to be another scorching hot day today at Wimbledon, with maximum temperatures reaching 31C (88F), according to forecasters          Although it was mainly England fans at Wimbledon, Amanda Strang (pictured) is a Sweden fan who also looks set to enjoy Wimbledon ahead of the match          The influence of the football was widespread with a number of fans dressed in England shirts and looking in high spirits          Some England fans found a novel way to express their support for their country as they wore hats with a passionate Gareth Southgate on them           Sir Bobby Charlton was spotted visiting Wimbledon today despite the England vs Sweden World Cup quarter-final being just hours away          England and Liverpool footballer Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain missed the World Cup through injury and he was also at Wimbledon          The former World Cup winner and England legend joined a host of other sporting personalities to watch the tennis, with British number one Kyle Edmund set to take on Novak Djokovic          Fans could be seen enjoying the sun as they relaxed ahead of the big tennis clash which sees Edmund face Djokovic as Britain's last hope          There may be some ision in the Edmund camp with his coach, Fredrik Rosengren, being Swedish and his match starting an hour or so after the England tie          With Edmund and England's football team both in action today, fans are set for an exciting day of action and seemed to be well-set          Former England footballer Bobby Charlton and his wife Norma take their seat in the Royal box on Centre Court before watching Spain's Rafael Nadal play against Australia's Alex De Minaur          Jessica Ennis-Hill was another of the sporting royalty to take their place in the centre court Royal box at Wimbledon today, as they await Kyle Edmund's match          Former England cricket captain  Andrew Strauss was also in the royal box on centre court ahead of Edmund's crunch match          Olympic gold medalist swimmer Adam Peaty looked dapper in a white suit as he took his place in the Royal box today          Former Rugby legend Dr J P R Williams (pictured) is also on the royal box on centre court today,  on day six of the Wimbledon          Commentator Barry Davies also turned up to watch Edmund, with the 23-year-old British number one on court at 4.15pmIt was set to be a hot day at Wimbledon, with maximum temperatures of 31C (88F), forecasters said.Spectators were slapping on the sun cream with UV levels likely to become very high by mid-afternoon.And the football influence was clear at Wimbledon as several fans wore England shirts and brandished flags ahead of the  tie.Some could be seen enjoying a pint and basking in the sunshine as they flocked to Murray Mound ahead of the Edmund-Djokovic clash.   Coach Rosengren said: 'To play one of the best guys ever in tennis on the mostfamous court on home soil, in my opinion it can't be bigger than that.'That is something he has to be very proud of. He has achieved so much so it's great, but at the same time you have to find a balance of not being too excited,you go in and try to play to win. He is in unbelievably good shape mentally. We talk a lot about that, to enjoy it. Sometimes we all forget the joy of playing.'The shocks continued in the women's draw on Friday, with last year's runner-up Venus Williams and her American compatriot Madison Keys joining the exodus of top-10 seeds.Only Simona Halep and Karolina Pliskova remain, but Serena Williams is looming large after beating Kristina Mladenovic to reach round four. Roger Federer made it 29 consecutive sets won at Wimbledon as the men's draw remained much more predictable so far.           Judy Murray and Strictly dancer Neil Jones were also in attendance ahead of the match between Edmund and Djokovic          Former boxing world champion joined Sir Bobby Charlton as one of the sporting personalities visiting Wimbledon          Despite the football match which began at 3pm, thousands of fans turned up for the sixth day of action at Wimbledon today          Former England Rugby captain Chris Robshaw and singer Camilla Kerslake were among the stars attending day six  Coach Fredrik Rosengren wants Kyle Edmund to enjoy facing Novak Djokovic ahead of their contest on Centre Court today          Former Tennis players Billie Jean King and Rod Laver (pictured) were among the stars in the royal box on centre court today          Large groups of spectators could be seen queuing up in the sunshine ahead of an exciting day's play at Wimbledon (pictured)          With Andy Murray ruled out and all the British women eliminated, Kyle Edmund was Britain's last hope at the tournament

title: England fans queue outside pubs FIVE hours watch World Cup clash Sweden
story: It didn't go too well for one man in Clapham Junction, London, who jumped off the roof of a bus on to the top of a bus shelter while singing the Three Lions song - but went straight through the glass          An England fan pulls up her top while standing on the bonnet of an ambulance in Borough, London, as other revellers gasp in awe          Three Lions supporters around the country celebrated wildly as England brilliantly beat Sweden 2-0 in the World Cup quarter final          Several celebrating fans jumped on the bonnet of an emergency vehicle in Borough High Street, leaving it severely dented - much to the annoyance of London Ambulance          'Obviously we are chuffed with the result this afternoon but there is absolutely NO excuse to vandalise emergency service vehicles by jumping on them,' it wrote on TwitterSergeant Wayne Baker, with West Yorkshire Police, tweeted his disgust after pictures emerged of revellers dancing on top of an ambulance in central London.He wrote: 'When I see behaviour like this it makes me anything but proud to be English .... You are a total disgrace. As for our National Football Team ... that does make me proud to be English!' PC Mark Walsh, from Hampshire Police tweeted a picture of the NHS car being stamped on: 'THAT is an NHS rapid response vehicle that the hard earned &amp much needed public money pays for. THAT is not how you support our fantastic #ENG squad’s efforts or our nation. THIS behaviour is a disgrace &amp you ought to be ashamed of yourself' he said.  London Ambulance Service published images of the damage to the vehicle.They wrote: 'We're delighted with the result, but this has put a big dampener on the celebrations for us: while our officer attended a call nearby, this car was damaged in Borough High Street during the celebrations after the game, it's now off the road to be repaired.'Several celebrating fans jumped on the bonnet of an emergency vehicle in Borough High Street, leaving it severely dented - much to the annoyance of London Ambulance.'Obviously we are chuffed with the result this afternoon but there is absolutely NO excuse to vandalise emergency service vehicles by jumping on them,' it wrote on Twitter.'This vehicle is now off the road and unable to respond to patients. We are better than this England.'  A spokesman for the Met said there had not been a spike in call-outs, despite the hysteria following England's victory over Sweden.           London Ambulance Service published images of the damage to the vehicle - saying they were delighted with the result but not the actionsThe antics were in contrast to more responsible fans who were cheering, singing and jumping around celebrating the 2-0 win over Sweden while dousing one another in beer as they celebrated the goals.They had queued up for four hours outside pubs in boiling heat to watch the Three Lions take on Sweden in their quarter final clash.Other excited fans got excited at England's first semi-final qualifier since 1990, and participated in some over-the-top antics frowned upon by authorities.Other fans were seen riding on the bonnet of a car driving through a street crowded with celebrating revellers soon after England's victory  The driver, who clearly couldn't see past the men blocking his windscreen, almost crashed into a a family crossing the street with their dog. Then the fans on the car were then sent tumbling off the car, and one of them appeared to be run over by the car as it sped offOther fans were seen riding on the bonnet of a car driving through a street crowded with celebrating revellers soon after England's victory.The two shirtless men raised their beers to their compatriots, who cheered them on until a near miss at a pedestrian crossing.The driver, who clearly couldn't see past the men blocking his windscreen, almost crashed into a a family crossing the street with their dog.The mother and father were barely able to jump out of the way as the car screeched to a halt too late, pulling their small child out of the way by inches.          Other shirtless fans were seen dancing on the top of buses while waving their drinks in the air along with England flags as traffic was brought to a standstill (fans in Birmingham pictured)    The lads on top of this bus in Manchester were quite over excited, dancing and waving their flags at a cheering crowd          Dozens of fans jumped on top of this bus in Manchester as post-match parties got a bit out of hand          The bus had nowhere to go as it got stuck in the street that was flooded with celebrating fans in central ManchesterThe fans on the car were then sent tumbling off the car as it stopped suddenly, and one of them appeared to be run over by the car as it sped off.Other shirtless fans were seen dancing on the top of buses while waving their drinks in the air along with England flags as traffic was brought to a standstill.   The match was held on the same weekend as the London Pride Parade, Wireless Festival and British Summertime Hyde Park, which brought swathes of tourists to the capital.Videos posted to social media saw huge crowds fill the streets in cities across the country after the team made it through to the World Cup semi-finals.In Nottingham, a group of supporters were seen dancing on top of a bus shelter, while other clips from Manchester and Birmingham showed people on top of buses with their shirts off.Footage from Clapham, south London, sees a fan plunge through a glass bus stop roof after leaping from the top of a double-decker bus. The England midfielder prepares to head the ball to the back of the net to put the Three Lions 2-0 up The Three Lions took first blood in the fixture courtesy of Harry Maguire, rising highest on the half hour mark to meet an Ashley Young corner and send the ball crashing into the back of the net.After surviving an early scare in the second half, England soon had their second, with Dele Alli heading home Jesse Lingard's first-time, curling cross. Gareth Southgate and his men will now take on Croatia on Wednesday at 7pm.The win sent shockwaves through the UK as 32 million England fans exploded with joy after watching the Three Lions make it through to the semi-final of a World Cup for the first time since 1990.          England's date with destiny got off to a dream start after centre back Harry Maguire scored a header to put England 1-0 up at the 30 minute mark          The 25-year-old defender's first goal at international level helped send his country through to the semis for the first time in three decadesBeers were thrown, shirts ripped off and flags waved as jubilant fans went wild when the final whistle was blown and England's fate was sealed. Defender Kieran Trippier - who has created 12 chances for England this World Cup - was praised by his father Chris after the final whistle.He told MailOnline: ‘I’m so proud of my son, now he’s in the World Cup semi-final. I used to watch him play in a park in Bury, England are going to win.’ Kensington Palace congratulated the team on its most successful World Cup in almost three decades, telling Harry Kane's squad they are 'making history' and echoing chants of 'football's coming home' heard across the country this afternoon.It came after The Bands of the Guards Division played a version of 'Three Lions - It's Coming Home' on the forecourt of Buckingham Palace yesterday.           Victorious exit: The England team leaves Samara after progressing to their first semi-final in 28 years following their win against Sweden today           Gareth Southgate leaves the stadium with 'job done' after the Three Lions beat Sweden to head into the semi-finals of Russia's World Cup           Trent Alexander-Arnold and Jordan Henderson signing balls at the airport as they leave Samara following their win over Sweden today           Sliding into the semis! title: Soft deal EU cost Tories power heavier defeat 1997
story: Agreeing a soft Brexit with Brussels will cost the Tories power in a defeat which could be heavier than 1997, Brexiteer MPs have warned Theresa May (pictured today in Maidenhead with husband Philip)          Eurosceptics, many of whom are led by Jacob Rees-Mogg (file image), feel betrayed at the Brexit blueprint the Prime Minister forced her Cabinet to accept in a major showdown at Chequers on Friday.Eurosceptics told the Sunday Telegraph finalising a deal on Friday's blueprint - involving a 'common rulebook' with the EU - would be a 'seismic moment'.They said it would encourage millions of voters buy into opposition party assertions that the Conservatives 'do not care about ordinary people'.The source warned: 'If that narrative takes hold, 1997 will look like a vicar's tea party.'Voters back Theresa May over her Brexit deal but Labour has...Boris in four-letter attack on May: Foreign Secretary stuns...Share this article    Mrs May published her 12-point Brexit blueprint following an historic showdown with her Cabinet on Friday night 'In detailed discussions the Cabinet has agreed our collective position for the future of our negotiations with the EU,' Mrs May said on Friday night.'Now we must all move at pace to negotiate our proposal with the EU to deliver the prosperous and secure future all our people deserve.'The statement came after a bitter war of words over Mrs May's plan that had threatened to spiral out of control. It drew immediate dismay from backbench Tories who said Britain would be a 'rule taker'.But the premier tried to capitalise on the apparent triumph tonight by stamping her authority on Cabinet.In a letter to Tory MPs she said collective responsibility on Brexit was suspended by David Cameron during the referendum and since then she had allowed Cabinet members to 'express their inidual views' in public without being sacked.But in a clear message to Mr Johnson, she added: 'Agreement on this proposal marks the point where that is no longer the case and collective responsibility is now fully restored.' title: Brexiteers blame Michael Gove leading betrayal referendum
story: Michael Gove (pictured today on Marr) was lashed as the 'snake in the grass' responsible for betraying the referendum today - but he insisted May's Brexit blueprint does honour the vote          The Environment Secretary admitted to Andrew Marr (pictured) the draft plans agreed at Friday's showdown were a balance between Leave and Remain ministers - but insisted the Government had resolved not to make 'perfect the enemy of the good'          As accounts of what happened at Chequers on Friday continued to emerge today, the Environment Secretary was slammed as a 'busted flush' after it was revealed he spoke up for Theresa May's (pictured today in Maidenhead) soft Brexit blueprintBut speaking to the BBC's Andrew Marr today, Mr Gove said his actions had been those of a 'realist'.Asked if the deal was all he hoped for, Mr Gove said: 'No, but then I'm a realist and one of the things about politics is you mustn't, you shouldn't make the perfect the enemy of the good.Russia are dumped out of World Cup after host nation loses...Is this the worst parenting ever? Man takes on bull with a...Share this article    Anger at Mrs May's proposals was growing today. Veteran Brexiteer Sir Bill Cash (pictured today on Sky News) said the proposals left 'a lot of questions'All of the Brexiteers in the Cabinet signed off on the plans on Friday night - even Mr Johnson despite telling the meeting it was a 'turd'. Eurosceptic MPs lashed the ministers today.One Brexiteer lashed Mr Gove as 'the main snake in the grass', after he spoke up in favour of Mrs May's plan during a 12-hour meeting of the Cabinet at Chequers. Another senior MP told the Telegraph: 'They should have spoken for Britain.'They failed. They are selfish iniduals who put career before country. 'It is pretty bloody obvious they prefer their ministerial cars.'Mr Gove's decision may backfire and destroy his rekindled leadership ambitions. 'His pretensions to being a credible leader have been blown to smithereens,' said one senior Brexiteer to the paper.'He's a busted flush.' An ally of Mr Johnson said: 'There is no doubt we would be heading for an even softer Brexit had Boris not been around the table.' Anger at Mrs May's proposals was growing today.Veteran Brexiteer Sir Bill Cash said the proposals left 'a lot of questions' and warned the Prime Minister a confidence vote was unstoppable if 48 Tory MPs write to 1922 Committee chairman Graham Brady.Sir Bill told Sky News: 'There's a lot of unhappiness.. is this going to be a proper Brexit?' Tory MP Andrew Bridgen told Radio 5Live: 'I'm very, very disappointed with the offer that we've seen coming out of Chequers. I'm disappointed that so called Brexiteers in the Cabinet didn't pick up the cudgels and fight for a better offer.'Bearing in mind this is an offer it's not a deal because it will be undoubtedly from the record, further diluted by the EU during negotiations. T'To be honest having looked at the three page summary, I haven't seen the 120 page detail, but I imagine that it will have been spun by No 10 as that's the best of the deal.'I've seen Martin Howe QC's legal opinion. I wouldn't support this deal if the EU were paying us.'    Boris Johnson, pictured left, stunned fellow ministers with a four-letter dismissal of Theresa May's Brexit plan during Friday's Chequers meeting after Mrs May, right, called for loyaltyToday's accounts of Friday's showdown revealed Foreign Secretary Mr Johnson stunned fellow Ministers with his four-letter dismissal of the Prime Minister's plan at Friday's special Chequers summit designed to unite the Cabinet. His comment risks making him the first victim of Mrs May's fresh crackdown on dissent.Mr Johnson – who has been accused of betrayal by Tory Brexiteers for not blocking Mrs May's 'soft Brexit' proposals – spoke out against the plan for the UK to remain in Bline with Brussels rules in a new free trade zone with the EU.According to a reliable source, he complained that anyone obliged to defend the proposals would be 'polishing a turd'.He added sarcastically: 'Luckily we have some expert turd polishers' – shooting a glance at one of Mrs May's spin doctors.Challenging the Prime Minister's new policy to her face, he said that her decision to try to 'align' UK trading rules with the EU would reduce Britain to the humiliating status of a 'vassal state'.He also took issue with her cher-ished new customs plan, the Facilitated Customs Arrangement (FCA), claiming it would be a 'serious inhibitor' to striking new trade deals with non-EU countries.His outburst was revealed just hours after Mrs May tried to draw a red line under weeks of open dissent from her Ministers, vowing that from now on she will enforce collective Cabinet responsibility and sack any Ministers who defy her. Some senior Tories believe she may be forced to fire Mr Johnson.    The outburst was revealed hours after Mrs May threatened to sack disloyal ministersA Mail on Sunday poll today endorses her handling of the Cabinet showdown, with 33 per cent of voters supporting her Brexit plan and 23 per cent opposing it. The Survation poll, the first survey since the Chequers summit, suggests Mrs May has twice the support of Mr Johnson – although voters do not believe her plan is 'faithful' to the EU referendum result.Last night, Eurosceptic Tories said there was so much anger at the PM's 'sell-out' that some MPs would submit no-confidence letters to force a challenge to her leadership.And Jacob Rees-Mogg's pro-Brexit European Research Group said experts believe the Chequers deal left the UK 'on course for a 'black hole' Brexit' – meaning we would be sucked into the orbit of EU rules with no hope of escape.          Boris Johnson has launched an extraordinary four-letter attack on PM Theresa May over her Brexit plansMr Johnson made clear in the run-up to Friday's session that he was vehemently against any scheme which left us shackled to EU rules, leading to fears in Downing Street that he and other pro-Brexit Ministers could resign.But Mrs May launched her own plan to kill off his revolt: signalling in advance she had already lined up 'talented' junior Ministers to replace any Cabinet quitters forcing all those at the summit to hand over their phones to stop them briefing against her under the table and issuing an official No 10 communique declaring victory while her critics were still stuck inside arguing.          Tory MP Andrew Bridgen has accused Boris Johnson of raising the white flag over BrexitThis so-called Brexit deal is nothing short of a betrayal of the 17.4 million people who voted to leave the EU. What on earth were the staunch Leavers in the Cabinet doing?Where was Boris Johnson? At Chequers on Friday, we needed him to emulate his hero, Winston Churchill. Instead, he gave us a modern-day version of Neville Chamberlain.Sadly, the Foreign Secretary was not alone in apparently waving the white flag of appeasement in the direction of Brussels. Other Brexiteer buccaneers and recent Brexit converts also jumped ship.The door to Mrs May's country residence was open but they chose not to walk out of it. Perhaps the threat of the withdrawal of the Government limo was just too great.This is a huge mistake on two grounds. Firstly, all those harbouring leadership hopes have done their ambitions fatal harm. Grassroots party members will have no truck with their perceived treachery. Some will try to keep their leadership hopes alive by claiming it was not the time to quit and they had a duty to stay on to ensure Brexit is not further watered down. But it leaves only one credible contender with the integrity and backbone to follow Mrs May: Jacob Rees-Mogg.Secondly, Brexiteer Cabinet Ministers are losing their nerve at the wrong time. This is not the end of the battle – it is the start of the real fight for a true Brexit. What Theresa May unveiled last week appears little short of a punishment Brexit, designed by the EU to dissuade any other country from leaving the bloc.With no incentive to offer non-EU countries free trade deals when we leave, through mutual recognition of standards, the UK will forever remain a captive market for overpriced EU goods. It means going through the pretence of leaving but becoming a non-voting associate member, a vassal state.We would still be locked into the EU's suffocating embrace via this 'common rule book' while the dead hand of the European Court of Justice will be lurking in the background.In contrast, we should call Brussels' bluff and, if necessary, leave without a formal deal. A so-called 'no deal' scenario may sound scary but 'no deal' does not actually mean no deal. It simply means the UK would trade on WTO terms which we use already to trade with most of the world.The fight to deliver a proper Brexit starts here and now. How Brexiteers' hopes were shattered by a single meeting

Weary moggies give a masterclass in CAT...The one result he didn’t see coming: Rabiot the octopus -...Share this articleA new law forces Polish judges to retire at 65 rather an 70.The move effectively wipes  out swathes of the country's judiciary including the country's chief judge, Malgorzata Gersdorf.The decision has seen thousands take to the streets in Poland in protest.

title: Marr sports Gareth Southgates favourite garment joins wave World Cup euphoria
story: The Scottish presenter is looking nifty in the five button dark blue waistcoat, with the bottom button left purposely undone- much like England boss Southgate          England were victorious in a surprisingly comfortable win over Sweden at the Samara Arena, with Harry Maguire and Dele Alli bagging the winning goalsNothing has summed up this England team more than the calm, collected, polite persona of their manager dressed in his formal waistcoast.In many ways the waistcoat sums up Gareth Southgate's personality to a tee- good-natured, polite and wholesome.Share this article The last button is always undone, to give the impression, he can, when he wants to, have a bit of fun.Marr was not the only one who decided to make the in-vogue fashion choice.Over on Channel 4, Sunday Brunch hosts Tim Lovejoy and Simon Rimmer also opted to wear 'lucky' waistcoats for the morning's broadcast.          England will now face Croatia in the semi-final at the Luzhniki Stadium, in Moscow on Wednesday eveningLovejoy and Rimmer asked viewers to send in pictures of themselves celebrating England's historic win against Sweden in the quarter-final on Saturday, with 'extra points' given to people in Southgate-style waistcoats.BBC Breakfast sports presenter John Acres wore a paper waistcoat during Sunday's programme.BBC Breakfast tweeted: 'Who else was loving our sport presenter @JohnAcres48? No one else could rock a paper waistcoat quite like him! £ChannellingSouthgate £GarethSouthgateWaistcoat £WorldCup.'The waistcoat craze reached actor Hugh Grant, who tweeted on Saturday ahead of the game: 'Like so many today am wearing a waistcoat. Just a waistcoat.'BBC Breakfast presenter Dan Walker has suggested that if the waistcoat continues to grow in popularity, it could have a positive effect for Marks &amp Spencer, the official tailors to the England team.He wrote, after England's latest success: 'If this carries on Gareth Southgate could save Marks &amp Spencer £Waistcoat.'And fans are now desperate to mimic their new found hero- with Marks and Spencer seeing a 35 per cent rise in waistcoat sales following success in Russia.          The waistcoat is becoming increasingly popular with fans, as a number of retailers have reported an increased demand for the product          Dele Alli rises high to score the second goal of the match, in which England beat Sweden 2-0Ebay has also reported a 25 per cent increase in searches for waistcoats and tailors TM Lewin have also reported an increase in demand.According to Google search data between July 3 and July 4, searches on the search engine for waistcoats shot up, following the team's win against Colombia.The charity Bloodwise has also suggested a Waistcoat Wednesday drive for the day of England's semi-final game against Croatia.          Ebay has also reported a 25 per cent increase in searches for waistcoats and tailors TM Lewin have also reported an increase in salesOn its website, the blood cancer research charity asked fans to 'show your support for Gareth Southgate and the boys ahead of Wednesday's semi-final showdown - and help give blood cancer the boot.'The organisation said: 'In honour of the England boss' new-found football fashionista status, we're inviting supporters to grab a waistcoat (or print one - in England colours of course!) and button up to beat blood cancer.'Taking part is simple: proudly display our poster to encourage everyone to don their favourite armless attire, make a donation towards life-changing blood cancer research and get ready to celebrate as the Three Lions sail through to the finals!'On Twitter there is even a #GarethSouthgateWould which invents a number of different scenarios the good-natured England manager might get up to.@frankelslowbro said: '#GarethSouthgateWould eat all the bounties from the celebration box so you don't have to.'

title: Businesses slam Theresa Mays Brexit blueprint complicated
story: The new letter was coordinated by Richard Reed (file image) the founder of Innocent Drinks More than 100 business leaders and entrepreneurs dismissed Theresa May's Brexit blueprint and demanded an even softer exit.The group - which includes the founders of Innocent Drinks, Pret a Manger and Waterstones - complained about the 'cost, complexity and bureaucracy' proposed.  The Prime Minister won the backing of her Cabinet on Friday for a hybrid proposal that effectively creates a a common market on goods but would leave Britain free in other areas.Business figures want her to go even further and stay inside the EU customs union - and hope to bolster a Remain Tory rebellion in the Commons next week. At the same time the draft deal - which has not been put to Brussels yet - has been lashed by Brexiteers as betraying the EU referendum.Brexiteers blast 'snake in the grass' Gove for backing May's...A soft Brexit will see an even bigger landslide LABOUR...Share this articleThe letter, revealed by the Observer and Sunday Times today, was organised by Richard Reed, a co-founder of Innocent Drinks.It has been signed by the founders of Pret a Manger, Waterstones, Zoopla, Net-a-Porter, Domino's Pizza, Yo! Sushi and Jack Wills.It states: 'The cost, complexity and bureaucracy created by crashing out of the customs union and adopting alternative arrangements is the last thing that our businesses need as we seek to grow and employ more people.'It would amount to the British government tying the hands of British business.'          The group - which includes the founders of Innocent Drinks, Pret a Manger (pictured is boss Julian Metcalfe) and Waterstones - complained about the 'cost, complexity and bureaucracy' proposed          The chief of Domino's Pizza (file image also signed up tot the plan backing continued membership of the customs union The letter urges MPs to 'put aside party political and ideological interests' by backing amendments tabled by the Conservative MP Anna Soubry and Labour's Chuka Umunna.Mr Umunna said Britain was heading for a 'bad Brexit deal' and the amendments were a 'last chance for parliament to put the brakes on.          The Prime Minister (pictured today in Maidenhead) won the backing of her Cabinet on Friday for a hybrid proposal that effectively creates a a common market on goods but would leave Britain free in other areas.He said: 'That is why we are working with colleagues in all parties  those who support a people's vote on the final Brexit deal, as I do, as well as those who want a Brexit deal that does the least damage to British businesses which keep people in work.'Veteran Brexiteer Sir Bill Cash said the proposals left 'a lot of questions' and warned the Prime Minister a confidence vote was unstoppable if 48 Tory MPs write to 1922 Committee chairman Graham Brady.Sir Bill told Sky News: 'There's a lot of unhappiness.. is this going to be a proper Brexit?'   Tory Remainers have broadly welcomed progress towards a softer Brexit.Writing in the Observer today, Tory Nicky Morgan, who chairs the all-party Treasury select committee, says the proposed free-trade area 'sounds remarkably like the common market'.In a dig at Johnson, who reportedly commented 'f*** business' when reacting to claims that some firms would take jobs abroad, Ms Morgan said: 'The cabinet have very deliberately chosen to listen to business and not swear at them or ask them to keep quiet.'That is good for our future prosperity.'          The letter urges MPs to 'put aside party political and ideological interests' by backing amendments tabled by the Conservative MP Anna Soubry and Labour's Chuka Umunna

title: Stunning colourised images bring life bravery British troops 75 years WWII
story: During the invasion of Sicily, the Liberty ship Robert Rowan (K-40) has been hit by a German Ju 88 bomber and its cargo of munitions explodes off Gela, Sicily. The plume contains a significant amount of toxic substances          US Sherman M4 tank lands during Operation Husky in Sicily in 1943 as the allied forces arrived on the island to fight Nazi Germany           A 5.5-inch gun was used by men in the 212nd Medium Regiment, Royal Artillery, on 23 July, 1943. The conflict led to the infamous dictator and architect of fascism Benito Mussolini's end          Stunning colour images took months to create as black and white photographs were transformed. Pictured: British troops in Pachine during the advance through Sicily          Italians wave an American flag as Allied troops walk past. The images which have been colourised show brave troops smiling at locals as they prepared for Operation Husky          Just after dawn men of the Highland Division are up to their waists in water unloading stores from landing craft tanks. Meanwhile beach roads are being prepared for heavy and light traffic during dawn of the opening day of the invasion of Sicily          Troops wade ashore from landing ships as they landed in Sicily ready to take on the Axis powers of Italy and Nazi Germany           Royal Air Force Eagles getting ready for Operation Husky on Sicily. Royston Leonard from Cardiff, Wales, who restored the shots said he could see 'brothers and sons' as he stared at the troops - and not just soldiers heading for warIt began with a large amphibious and airborne operation, followed by a six-week land campaign, and initiated the Italian Campaign.The original black and white photographs were painstakingly colourised over a number of months by electrician Royston Leonard  from Cardiff, Wales.'These images show young people getting ready to face war to bring freedom back to Europe,' the 55-year-old said.'When you look at these pictures you can see fathers, sons, brothers not soldiers. Yes they are soldiers but only a short time before they had been neighbours and friends or family.'They will only see Italy on a postcard': Country's interior...'There are no baby prostitutes only sexually abused...A car built for the Führer: Hitler's 1939 armor-plated...Share this article    US troops make their way through the smoke to Fontainebleau, en route to Paris, during World War II as the allied forces make a bid to take Europe back from fascists 'The pictures show what had to be done and by looking at them we can keep in mind to please never let it happen again.' Husky began on the night of 9-10 July 1943, and ended on 17 August. Strategically, Husky achieved the goals set out for it by Allied planners the Allies drove Axis air, land and naval forces from the island and the Mediterranean sea lanes were opened for Allied merchant ships for the first time since 1941.The Italian leader, Benito Mussolini, was toppled from power in Italy and the way was opened for the Allied invasion of Italy. The German leader, Adolf Hitler, cancelled a major offensive at Kursk after only a week, in part to ert forces to Italy, resulting in a reduction of German strength on the Eastern Front.The collapse of Italy necessitated German troops replacing the Italians in Italy and to a lesser extent the Balkans, resulting in one fifth of the entire German army being erted from the east to southern Europe, a proportion that would remain until near the end of the war.           Images of troops in Sicily have been colourised for the first time in the 75th anniversary year of Operation Husky which took place in 1943          General Bernard Law Montgomery is bid a jolly farewell by Lieutenant General George S Patton, Jr at the Palermo, Sicily airport after a visit by General Montgomery

title: Windsor Maidenhead Borough Council rakes 71 000 parking fees Royal Wedding Day
story: The Windsor and Maidenhead Borough Council made £71,000 an hour when the Royal couple tied the knot on May 19Windsor and Maidenhead Borough Council said it had not estimated the overall cost of the event as invoices were still being processed, according to the Sunday Express. It added 'much of the expenses will be refunded by the Department for Media, Culture and Sport'.The information was found through a Freedom of Information Request.  Many regarded the Royal wedding a success, however, 11 Windsor residents made complaints about it - with one slamming spectators who trampled their gardening club's carefully manicured flower beds.           Thousands descended on Windsor for the event causing the streets to be packed with carsThe Kennedys take aim at Melania and President Trump: Ethel...EXCLUSIVE: The Underbelly star and the revenue-raising...Share this articleAnother resident was furious that they paid £200 to recover a car that had been towed away by police.Another dubbed the hike in parking charges– from £8 a day to £12 – 'extortionate'.A driver said to the Express: 'You are exploiting the increase in visitors due to the upcoming wedding by raising parking prices,' said another driver.Windsor and Maidenhead Borough Council has been approached by Mail Online for comment.Meghan Markle and Prince Harry's royal wedding made Windsor £71,000 in parking fees | Royal | News | Express.co.uk

title: Royal rail travel criticised Queen joins thousands taking aim Govia Thameslink
story: The Queen has reportedly told crisis-hit train bosses she preferred older train models for her travel to SandringhamRail delays have infuriated everyday passengers across Britain, but now, one major firm is in for a right royal ticking off - because The Queen does not like their new service, it is claimed.  A chief from the crisis-hit Govia Thameslink Railway told a meeting Her Majesty is not happy with their new trains, because she does not like the seats.The royal has aired her preference for the older trains when she uses the VIP service to visit her country estate in Sandringham, Norfolk, it was claimed.The two-hour journey was made on the 365 train in the past but the new model, the 387, has not been given the royal seal of approval.According to The Sun, the manager said: 'The Queen doesn't like the new trains - she prefers the old ones to take her to Kings Lynn'.Her Majesty joins thousands of people who are no longer happy with GTR. This week security was brought in at some stations to help staff because of rising anger.GTR's passenger services director Stuart Cheshire made the revelation about the Queen at a meeting for infuriated rail users in Hitchin, Hertforshire.          Pictured: Queen Elizabeth II boards a Great Northern train at King's Lynn Station to return to London after her Christmas break at Sandringham HousePrivate planes, TV appearances, and out until 5am? Not in my...Meghan Markle breaks another Royal rule by trying to hold...Share this articleThe meeting was held over mass complaints that the new timetable being operated is being mishandled as there is a driver shortage.  GTR runs the Thameslink, Great Northern, Southern and Gatwick Express airport services.           Protests took place in 2016 as Govia Thameslink services by Southern Rail were cancelled and hit with major delays           Commuters said they were repeatedly unable to see their children because of major delays In two weeks after the new timetable began in May, thirteen per cent of services were cancelled or hit with major delays.MP for the area, Bim Afolami said: 'Since the new GTR timetables came into effect this week we have seen nothing but chaos. This is affecting thousands of my constituents, and it is simply not good enough from GTR. The changes are affecting work and personal lives, with little concern for the impact they're having.'The furious politician revealed in June some of his constituents waited up to 28 days for compensation for some journeys, and received just £2.Train companies have been warned they have just weeks to turn things around of face having their franchise take away.

title: England fans queue outside pubs FIVE hours watch World Cup clash Sweden
story: It didn't go too well for one man in Clapham Junction, London, who jumped off the roof of a bus on to the top of a bus shelter while singing the Three Lions song - but went straight through the glass          An England fan pulls up her top while standing on the bonnet of an ambulance in Borough, London, as other revellers gasp in awe          Three Lions supporters around the country celebrated wildly as England brilliantly beat Sweden 2-0 in the World Cup quarter final          Several celebrating fans jumped on the bonnet of an emergency vehicle in Borough High Street, leaving it severely dented - much to the annoyance of London Ambulance          'Obviously we are chuffed with the result this afternoon but there is absolutely NO excuse to vandalise emergency service vehicles by jumping on them,' it wrote on TwitterSergeant Wayne Baker, with West Yorkshire Police, tweeted his disgust after pictures emerged of revellers dancing on top of an ambulance in central London.He wrote: 'When I see behaviour like this it makes me anything but proud to be English .... You are a total disgrace. As for our National Football Team ... that does make me proud to be English!' PC Mark Walsh, from Hampshire Police tweeted a picture of the NHS car being stamped on: 'THAT is an NHS rapid response vehicle that the hard earned &amp much needed public money pays for. THAT is not how you support our fantastic #ENG squad’s efforts or our nation. THIS behaviour is a disgrace &amp you ought to be ashamed of yourself' he said.  London Ambulance Service published images of the damage to the vehicle.They wrote: 'We're delighted with the result, but this has put a big dampener on the celebrations for us: while our officer attended a call nearby, this car was damaged in Borough High Street during the celebrations after the game, it's now off the road to be repaired.'Several celebrating fans jumped on the bonnet of an emergency vehicle in Borough High Street, leaving it severely dented - much to the annoyance of London Ambulance.'Obviously we are chuffed with the result this afternoon but there is absolutely NO excuse to vandalise emergency service vehicles by jumping on them,' it wrote on Twitter.'This vehicle is now off the road and unable to respond to patients. We are better than this England.'  A spokesman for the Met said there had not been a spike in call-outs, despite the hysteria following England's victory over Sweden.           London Ambulance Service published images of the damage to the vehicle - saying they were delighted with the result but not the actionsThe antics were in contrast to more responsible fans who were cheering, singing and jumping around celebrating the 2-0 win over Sweden while dousing one another in beer as they celebrated the goals.They had queued up for four hours outside pubs in boiling heat to watch the Three Lions take on Sweden in their quarter final clash.Other excited fans got excited at England's first semi-final qualifier since 1990, and participated in some over-the-top antics frowned upon by authorities.Other fans were seen riding on the bonnet of a car driving through a street crowded with celebrating revellers soon after England's victory  The driver, who clearly couldn't see past the men blocking his windscreen, almost crashed into a a family crossing the street with their dog. Then the fans on the car were then sent tumbling off the car, and one of them appeared to be run over by the car as it sped offOther fans were seen riding on the bonnet of a car driving through a street crowded with celebrating revellers soon after England's victory.The two shirtless men raised their beers to their compatriots, who cheered them on until a near miss at a pedestrian crossing.The driver, who clearly couldn't see past the men blocking his windscreen, almost crashed into a a family crossing the street with their dog.The mother and father were barely able to jump out of the way as the car screeched to a halt too late, pulling their small child out of the way by inches.          Other shirtless fans were seen dancing on the top of buses while waving their drinks in the air along with England flags as traffic was brought to a standstill (fans in Birmingham pictured)    The lads on top of this bus in Manchester were quite over excited, dancing and waving their flags at a cheering crowd          Dozens of fans jumped on top of this bus in Manchester as post-match parties got a bit out of hand          The bus had nowhere to go as it got stuck in the street that was flooded with celebrating fans in central ManchesterThe fans on the car were then sent tumbling off the car as it stopped suddenly, and one of them appeared to be run over by the car as it sped off.Other shirtless fans were seen dancing on the top of buses while waving their drinks in the air along with England flags as traffic was brought to a standstill.   The match was held on the same weekend as the London Pride Parade, Wireless Festival and British Summertime Hyde Park, which brought swathes of tourists to the capital.Videos posted to social media saw huge crowds fill the streets in cities across the country after the team made it through to the World Cup semi-finals.In Nottingham, a group of supporters were seen dancing on top of a bus shelter, while other clips from Manchester and Birmingham showed people on top of buses with their shirts off.Footage from Clapham, south London, sees a fan plunge through a glass bus stop roof after leaping from the top of a double-decker bus.          Several were arrested near London Bridge station as high spirits led to fights on side streets          They had to be broken up by police and the combatants dragged away in handcuffs          An England fan climbed a lamp post near London Bridge station after heavy drinking, much to the amusement of a huge crowd          Another fan hoisted himself on to the sign for the Underground station to get a better view of the revellry on the street          Once on top of the sign he balance precariously and waved an England flag in excitement following the huge win          Some fans further heightened the charged atmosphere by setting off smoke bombs that wafted over the crowdElsewhere, fans caused pandemonium in Nottingham as they smashed cars and destroyed an entire bus stop as celebrations got far out of hand.  In one video, a car can be seen with a smashed roof and windscreen in Nottingham.A crowd of supporters were also filmed rushing into an Ikea in Stratford, east London, dancing on the furniture and kicking items around.An Ikea spokeswoman said: 'We are aware of a small group of fans celebrating the match result in one of our stores.'Being both British and Swedish, we were on the edge of our seats during the game and we would like to say 'Grattis!' (that's congratulations in Swedish) to the England team for getting through to the semi-finals.'  Ambulance arrives at hospital as first two Thai football boys rescuedShocking footage shows Spanish police beating England fans in SpainFans get run over by car as they celebrate England's winMilitary helicopter believed to be carrying two of the Thai studentsCrazy scene in Birmingham as fans get on top of bus after England winCouple say they've decided to show the World Cup at their weddingNFL player Marquis Goodwin surprises mom with new housePM Theresa May confirms agreement of UK-EU free trade areaRescuers drill into cave ahead of Thai football team rescueIs this the moment Prince Harry got caught up in London's World Cup chaos?MPs arrive at Chequers for day of discussion around Brexit blueprint    Revellers party and drink in the streets of London, barely inconvenienced by the emergency vehicle parked in the road          The ambulance had its window smashed and the bonnet severely dented out of shape when fans jumped on it          One fan dressed as England manager Gareth Southgate - complete with his trademark waistcoat - stands victoriously on the ambulance          These fans in London could be seen cheering wildly and throwing beer around as Dele Alli added a second goal for England against Sweden    England fans in Croydon's Boxpark go wild as Deli Alli heads home second goal after Harry Maguire headed in the first           England fans in Bristol's Ashton Gate Stadium hurl beer in the air the moment Deli Alli scores England's second goal           The moment England fans in  Flat Iron Square, London believe World Cup glory could be theirs as Three Lions scored again          Now it's TWO! England fans scream with joy as Deli Alli heads home Three Lions' second goal against Sweden in World Cup They waited a long time for the party with some fervent football fans were pictured standing outside pubs in London as early as 10am this morning in sizzling 91.5F (33C) heat to secure a space inside. In Birmingham, fans took a seat on the canalside ahead of the game and sipped on pints in the sun. At the Rose and Crown pub in Wimbledon village, scores of fans gathered for the England game, including many who have left the tennis at Wimbledon.Those who have tickets for Saturday's tennis have been issued with pink and blue re-entry wristbands.There were chants of 'get the tennis off' as fans waited eagerly for the football to be put on the big screens.Clive McCabe, from Twickenham, has seats on Court One but has left to watch the football.He said: 'It's the most people who have left Wimbledon on middle Saturday between 1pm and 2pm.'He added: 'There's more people leaving than going in.'    Goal! Beer spills in the air as England fans celebrating Maguire's goal throw their arms up in joy          Celebrations! Fans celebrate after Harry Maguire nets England's first goal, putting them ahead of Sweden          Beer rockets into the skies in Bristol as Three Lions fans cheer with pride after Harry Maguire scores first goal in Sweden clash    YEESSSSS! Three Lions fans in London explode with joy as Harry Maguire heads home England's first goal in quarter-finalFans in Cheshire dressed up as England manager Gareth Southgate wearing his trademark navy suit and waistcoast.The group who headed out in Nantwich to catch the game wore light blue shirts and a stripy ties, and even wore with paper masks with the manager's face on.Last week, M&ampS revealed that sales of waistcoats, which Southgate has worn for every one of his four touchline appearances at England's matches, have rocketed by 35 per cent since the tournament began.          Back of the net! Fans celebrate Harry Maguire's goal at Flat Iron Square in south London          England fans celebrate the Three Lions first goal as they take on Sweden in the World Cup quarter finals at Ashton Gate          England fans celebrate the first goal from Harry Maguire at the Rose &amp Crown pub, in Wimbledon, south London          One - nil! Fans at a big screen in London celebrate as Harry Maguire scores a bullet header          It's coming home! Fans at Flat Iron Square in south London cheer on Harry Kane and the boys as England take on Sweden          Fans react to a near miss from England whilst watching coverage of the FIFA World Cup 2018 quarter-final match between Sweden and England at the Rose &amp Crown pub, in Wimbledon           Fans - many that have left the tennis in Wimbledon - react to a near miss from captain Harry Kane           A couple appear distracted by a device after England have kick off in a World Cup quarter final while Rafael Nadal and Alex De Minaur plays on Centre Court Wimbledon Tennis Championships          England fans go wild as they see Harry Maguire head home ball while watching on giant screen at London's Wireless festival             A football fan streams the World Cup Quarter Final action on a phone during the Rafael Nadal match on Centre Court Wimbledon Tennis Championships          England fans climb on one another shoulders to watch the match on the big screen at Flat Iron Square in Borough, London          Fans in Flat Iron Square get ready for the big game as they grab beers and wear Three Lions shirtsUp to 10,000 tickets go unsold for the England vs Sweden...England changes the channel: British hopeful Kyle Edmund...Not just their big day! Couples prepare to tie the knot as...Share this article    Fans ready to watch the coverage of the FIFA World Cup 2018 quarter-final match between Sweden and England at the Rose &amp Crown pub, in Wimbledon - many who have left the tennis to catch the Three Lions play          England fans arrive at Flat Iron Square in Borough in south London to catch the game          England fans arrive to watch the FIFA World Cup 2018 quarter-final match between Sweden and England at Luna Beach Cinema, Brighton          Beer we go! England fans cheer as they watch England v Sweden quarter-final clash in Bristol          England fans cheer on the Three Lions at Wimbledon where Britain's Kyle Edmund is set to play this Super Saturday          Three Lions roar: England fans show their support for Harry Kane's boys during day out at Wimbledon           Kiss of St George: England fans plant a smooch on Three Lions fan with red-and-white painted head at Croydon's Boxpark           England football fans in Croydon's Boxpark sing and cheer before the start of the England v Sweden quarter final match          England fans gather along the canalside in Birmingham ahead of the national team's quarter final game against Sweden          Three England fans don replica shirts to drink pints ahead of the Three Lions game with Sweden this afternoon  Fans excitedly pose draped in a cross of St George and England shirts...while one fan created a shirt of his own drawing the Three Lions on          Fans where hats and drink pints as they prepare to see the Three Lions take on the Swedish team          Fans in Bristol drape themselves in the pub of St. George and raise a glass to the Three Lions as they prepare to watch England take on Sweden          These supporters have been queuing up since 10am this morning to get into The George pub in London Bridge to watch today's tie          The fervent fans baked in sizzling 91.5F (33C) heat as they waited to secure a space inside the traditional English pub          A line wraps around the block outside of a pub in Clapham shortly before 12pm today - almost four hours before the match kicks off          England fans show support for Gareth Southgate and his team as they head out to watch the match in Nantwich dressed in Southgate trademark navy suit          All together now! Fans dress up as the England manager as they head to watch the Three Lions take on SwedenElsewhere, crowds flocked to outdoor big screens in cities including London, Birmingham, Liverpool, Manchester, Newcastle, Bristol, Exeter and Leeds to make the most of the beautiful weather while watching the game.To help keep cool - or steady the nerves - 38 million pints of beer are set to be drunk by fans as the latest chapter in captain Harry Kane and the team's Russian adventure triggers a £190million big-game drinks and food spree. Some 18 million pints are expected to be downed in pubs - seven million more than usual - with pub takings soaring to £100 million as a predicted 3.5 million fans pack the country's 40,000 pubs to watch the match.At home, 20 million pints are expected to be drunk today costing around £22 million, the British Beer and Pub Association (BBPA) said. Food spending on the match will add up to another £30 million in pubs and £40 million at home. However, not all of the UK was getting behind the Three Lions.Swedes and Scots packed into Akva, a Swedish bar in Edinburgh's west end, to watch the match.There was Swedish bunting and flags, with many fans wearing the side's yellow strip.A faulty connection added to the tension outside in the beer garden, where supporters groaned as the large screen showing the game repeatedly cut off.            Fans hold up 'It's Coming Home' signs and wear Three Lions shirts at Nass Festival in Bath          England fans get ready for the game ahead of the England Match at the Nass Festival in Bath          There was a massive queue outside of The Original Oak in Headingley, Leeds, this morning. Around 32 million viewers are expected to tune in to BBC1 to watch Gareth Southgate's men          Fans queue outside Water Poet in Liverpool Street, central London, this morning to watch England attempt to reach their first World Cup semi-final for 28 years           Dedicated supporters waited for hours outside other pubs in London Bridge. 38 million pints of beer are set to be drunk by fans          They could be seen singing and cheering as they celebrated while at the San Fermin festival in Pamplona, Spain          Fans from around the world were seen celebrating Harry Maguire's goal, such as these fans at the San Fermin festival in Spain  Eerie photos reveal empty streets, motorways with no traffic and a soulless Bluewater shopping centre during Three Lions clashWith so many watching the match, the nation will come to a halt with roads, high streets and train stations likely to be empty during the quarter-final, which will be shown live on BBC1.The RAC said it expects 'the quietest Saturday afternoon of the year, with deserted roads.'Shopping centres such as London's Oxford Street - one of the world's most famous shopping destinations - are also expected to be quieter than they typically would be on a Saturday afternoonElsewhere, shops and streets were deserted as everyone headed to the nearest screen to catch the game.Bluewater in Kent, one of the country's biggest shopping centres was like a ghost town.The usually bustling indoor shopping street saw barely anyone frequent the big name high street chains such as Waterstones, House of Fraser and Urban Outfitters.          An empty bluewater shopping centre minutes before England kicked off their quarter final match with Sweden          Fans clear out of shopping centres and head to the pub to watch England play          Bluewater shopping centre was exceedingly quiet as fans disappeared away from shops to watch the quarter finals          A deserted Tyne Bridge at 3pm today as fans head to the pub to watch England take on Sweden in the biggest Three Lions match in a decade

title: World Cup England Sweden players stride pitch Samara ahead World Cup Sweden clash
story: Jordan Pickford says England can make history this World Cup after the Three Lions beat Sweden 2-0 in yesterday's quarter-finals          Harry Kane will lead his men into the semi-finals against Croatia after Russia was knocked out of the World Cup shortly after England's victory           Dele Alli rises above the Swedish defence to score England's second header against Sweden in the quarter final clash          Go on, Dele! The England midfielder prepares to head the ball to the back of the net to put the Three Lions 2-0 up The Three Lions took first blood in the fixture courtesy of Harry Maguire, rising highest on the half hour mark to meet an Ashley Young corner and send the ball crashing into the back of the net.After surviving an early scare in the second half, England soon had their second, with Dele Alli heading home Jesse Lingard's first-time, curling cross. Gareth Southgate and his men will now take on Croatia on Wednesday at 7pm.The win sent shockwaves through the UK as 32 million England fans exploded with joy after watching the Three Lions make it through to the semi-final of a World Cup for the first time since 1990.          England's date with destiny got off to a dream start after centre back Harry Maguire scored a header to put England 1-0 up at the 30 minute mark          The 25-year-old defender's first goal at international level helped send his country through to the semis for the first time in three decadesBeers were thrown, shirts ripped off and flags waved as jubilant fans went wild when the final whistle was blown and England's fate was sealed. Defender Kieran Trippier - who has created 12 chances for England this World Cup - was praised by his father Chris after the final whistle.He told MailOnline: ‘I’m so proud of my son, now he’s in the World Cup semi-final.
