title: its fudge written over it
story: News"It's got fudge written all over it" - Labour's Keir Starmer savages Theresa May's Brexit plan as "unworkable"The shadow Brexit secretary savaged the Prime Minister's plan&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent11:47, 8 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour's Brexit chief has slammed Theresa May's hard-won compromise as unworkable. Keir Starmer described the Cabinet compromise as a fudge. Speaking to the BBC's Andrew Marr he said: We've argued for a comprehensive customs union with the EU. The Prime Minister has gone to extraordinary lengths to avoid that and come up with this plan which is not going to work. He said of the plan: It's got fudge written all over it. The Labour frontbencher called on Theresa May to put the plan which was hammered out at Chequers on Friday to a vote in the House of Commons.  I challenge the Prime Minister to put it to a vote. It comes as leading Brexiteer Michael Gove accused the BBC's Andrew Marr of asking fake questions as he struggled to defend the PM's new plan. The Environment Secretary was asked about the UK's future relationship with the European Courts of Justice - which many people who voted to Leave see as a red line for leaving the EU. The veteran interviewer asked Mr Gove if he could guarantee that the ECJ would have no influence on British public life going forward. The Government minister instead insisted that the ECJ would have an influence on Britain even if we had never joined the continental bloc because it would influence how we got goods and services into their markets. Mr Marr said in response: I think this is fake sovereignty. To which Mr Gove replied: I think you are wrong - I think that is a fake question.   Brexit: Theresa May's plan finally revealed as she reaches 'agreement' with warring Tories at Chequers summit  Asked if the deal was everything he hoped for, Mr Gove told BBC's Andrew Marr Show: No, but then I'm a realist and one of the things about politics is you mustn't, you shouldn't make the perfect the enemy of the good. One of the things about this compromise is that it unites the Cabinet.  He added: All those of us who believe that we want to execute a proper Brexit , and one that is the best deal for Britain, have an opportunity now to get behind the Prime Minister in order to negotiate that deal.  In a bid to solve the Northern Ireland issue, she now wants to keep the UK closely aligned with the EU in a new free trade area for goods. This will include sharing a common rulebook for all goods including agricultural and food products - which critics had feared would make it harder to get a US trade deal.

title: keir starmer calls labour listen
story: NewsKeir Starmer calls for Labour to listen to Jewish critics over new anti-Semitism rulesThe leading MP called for the party to adopt the full IHRA definition of anti-Semitism&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent13:14, 8 JUL 2018Updated14:24, 8 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLeading Labour MP Keir Starmer has called calls for Labour to listen to Jewish criticism of new anti-Semitism rules. The Party faced a backlash from many Jewish groups and supporters last week when it unveiled new guidelines for tackling anti-Jewish sentiment. Critics say the new rules stop short of incorporating the full International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance definition of anti-Jewish abuse. But the Party insists that their own guidelines actually go much further. Today the shadow Brexit Secretary stressed the importance of listening to those criticisms.  I think we need to reflect on what's been said in the last few days and if we're not in a position of supporting the full definition we need to get into that position and sharpish, he told the BBC's Andrew Marr.  Although Labour adopted the IHRA definition in 2016 it did not accept the examples which accompany it. This has been widely criticised. Keir Starmer said: I believe in the full definition. Councils, institutions across the country have accepted the full definition and I think that's the right position to be in. Asked why he thought Labour hadn't adopted it, he replied: There's some argument as to whether Labour has or hasn't but I would urge everybody within the Labour Party to listen to the voices that have come out in recent days and get to a position where we are supporting the full definition. I think it's really important - including the examples. We have to be really clear about our position on this. Labour's new general secretary Jennie Formby has defended the party's new guidance - saying it went further than the IHRA rules. Ms Formby, who Jeremy Corbyn has asked to stamp out antisemitism, said: I have been asked why we didn’t just adopt the IHRA’s examples as they are and leave it at that. The answer is that they do not go far enough for practical use by a political party.  Our guidelines address all of the ground covered by the IHRA examples, clarifies those that might be open to different interpretations or be seen as conflicting with other rights, and provides additional examples of anti-Semitic language and behaviour.  But asked this morning whether the party should rewrite the code after feedback from the Jewish community, Mr Starmer said: I think we need to reflect on what's been said in the last few days and if we are not in a position of supporting the full definition we need to get into that position and sharpish.

title: labours brexit chief refuses rule
story: NewsLabour's Brexit chief refuses to rule out a second referendumKeir Starmer said "all options ought to be on the table"&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent14:58, 8 JUL 2018NewsLabour is coming under increasing pressure to back a second vote (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour's Brexit chief has refused to rule out a second referendum on leaving the EU.  The Party's official position is not to back a second poll but Jeremy Corbyn is under increasing pressure to change this stance.  Scores of his own MPs back another vote, large swathes of the membership and the influential Momentum group back another vote. While last week Labour's biggest financial backer the Unite union left the door open to supporting one - after a majority of members at its policy conference backed one. On Friday Sir Keir Starmer said his party was not calling for another vote, but we're not ruling out a second referendum. Today he repeated that position when speaking to the BBC's Andrew Marr.   He said: In the event that Article 50 is voted down or there is no deal, that is a serious situation. Parliament should decide what happens next.   And at that stage, there could be a general election, there could be other options, but all options, it seems to me, ought to be on the table.  It comes after Theresa May secured a hard won and fragile compromise on the government's position on the future relationship with the EU after an away day at Chequers. The vulnerable PM broke the deadlock by coming up with a peace offering for both the Remain and Leave camps. In a bid to solve the Northern Ireland issue, she now wants to keep the UK closely aligned with the EU in a new free trade area for goods.  This will include sharing a common rulebook for all goods including agricultural and food products - which critics had feared would make it harder to get a US trade deal. The PM claimed this will help the UK avoid friction in trade - protecting jobs and businesses. But in a desperate bid to prevent Brexiteers resigning, she also said Parliament would keep the right to block future changes to the trading rules.  The olive branch to the Brexiteers means Mrs May remains vulnerable - because there is no guarantee the EU will accept her new plan.

title: theresa braces herself bid tory
story: NewsTheresa May braces herself for bid by Tory MPs to oust her over BrexitThe PM, due to address all 316 Tory MPs on Monday, is expecting enough of them to oppose her to mount a no-confidence vote on her leadership&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor21:56, 7 JUL 2018Newsrime Minister Theresa May and members of her Cabinet meet at her country retreat Chequers (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is bracing herself for a bid by Tory MPs to oust her following her soft Brexit fudge. The PM, due to address all 316 Tory MPs on Monday, is expecting enough of them to oppose her to mount a no-confidence vote on her leadership. But she relishes the opportunity to finally end the plotting against her. An aide told the Sunday Mirror: “Once it’s done, it’s done.” Although Mrs May got her new Brexit plan through Cabinet without any walkouts, ministers fear it will be rejected by Brussels. Europe goes on holiday in August. So only six weeks remain before an agreement must be reached at the EU Council summit in October.  Ministers have now stepped up their planning for a no-deal Brexit – while chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier is waiting to see whether the new proposal is “workable and realistic”. Brexit rebel leader Jacob Rees-Mogg warned he “will not vote for something which doesn’t deliver Brexit”. Graham Brady, chair of the backbench 1922 Committee, is believed to be just six letters short of the 48 needed to trigger a vote of no &shyconfidence in the PM. If Mrs May lost a vote she would have to stand down and there would be a leadership contest. But Tory Chief Whip Julian Smith, who briefed 40 MPs on the fudge yesterday, believes Mrs May would win a vote easily.

title: holiday firms charging single parent
story: NewsSingle-parents face holiday rip-off as travel firms charge up to a third more per person than family ratesAlready faced with prices soaring by more than £1,000 during the school holiday peak, lone parents say the ­additional hike can make it impossible to take their children away&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNada Farhoud20:54, 7 JUL 2018Updated12:33, 8 JUL 2018NewsMum Kate Grice, 40, from Sheffield, booked a holiday to Spain for her three-year-old and herself&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHoliday firms are charging single-parent families up to a third more per person than &shycouples with a child, a Sunday Mirror probe has found. Already faced with prices soaring by more than &pound1,000 during the school holiday peak, lone parents say the &shyadditional hike can make it impossible to take their children away. And operators such as Jet 2, Tui and First Choice can make the problem worse – as offers of free child places only apply if two paying adults travel with them. Single parent groups say the policy is “unfair” and “out of touch”. We found a one week all-inclusive stay at Bulgaria’s SuneoClub Odessos, &shyflying from Manchester on July 27, costs &pound1,572 for two adults with a free child’s place via First Choice.  But for just one adult and one child, the price is exactly the same. When selecting one adult, the ad for free child places disappears from the site. Airtours offers “child prices” for some hotels – but only when sharing a room with at least two adults paying full price. Thomas Cook Holidays has the same pricing policy. And because the firms do not count children in the room rate, a single parent can be charged an under-occupancy supplement. But it is not just accommodation – other firms also hit single parents with increased fares. A First Choice holiday to the Holiday Village Rhodes for seven nights cost an extra &pound515 per person for a single adult with one child.

title: how keep your kids cool
story: AdvertorialHow to keep your kids cool during the heatwave: 9 products which can help protect your little onesIce, ice baby. But failing that, here's how you can keep your family cool now the weather's turned hot&nbspShareByHolly Thatcher00:00, 5 JUL 2018Updated14:20, 6 JUL 2018Advertorial&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe're all having a lovely time in the summer sun thanks to this unexpected heatwave. But as nice as it is to have stolen the Australian summer, us Brits just aren't used to coping with sudden rises in temperature. Still, all it really takes is a bit of preparation. Here are our tips for keeping comfortable and safe in this glorious weather. Now get out there and enjoy! Hydrate early, hydrate often    Your body is two-thirds water and you need to keep it topped up. If you don't you'll get headaches and may also be more tired than usual. Hydration is, as most things are, even more important for little ones. According to the British Nutrition Foundation children are less heat tolerant than adults and have a higher percentage of water in their bodies. They're also tricky little monkeys who rarely remember to drink unless reminded. The key then, is going to be making it fun to grab a drink. If you have an outdoor power socket in your garden then connect up the Halfords 40 Litre Coolbox, &pound85 (was &pound110, save &pound25) and fill it with drinks. That way your kids can get their own chilled drink - they'll love this. You can just as easily put the coolbox inside if you don't have an outdoor power outlet. Alternatively, if you If you are planning to be out and about, you can also charge the cooler from your car's 12v power outlet. Make staying hydrated even more fun for the kids with a set of plastic Rainbow Tumblers, &pound3 (half price).  Be skin-savvy Being outside in the sunshine is enjoyable, but its UV rays can do lasting damage to your skin. Applying a high SPF sun cream is vital - but it's also best to avoid exposing your skin to direct sun for prolonged periods, especially between midday and 3pm, when the sun is strongest. This is especially important for kids. So with a cloudless, beautiful summer sky you're going to need to create some shade. If you're at the beach, then a dedicated shelter will help. Halfords' Beach Shelter offers a 30+ UV protection. If you're spending most of the day out in the garden and the kids are in and out of the paddling pool, you may need more protection. The Halfords 300 Gazebo costs just &pound69 ( was &pound90, save &pound21) and has a UV 50+ rating.  When choosing a gazebo or shelter for the sunny weather it's worth understanding those UV protection numbers. With a 50+ rating the gazebo should stop around 97 to 98 per cent of the UV radiation from the sun. This, combined with sun cream will help keep you all much safer. With any gazebo you might also want to consider some weights to go along with it. Just because it's sunny, doesn't mean it can't also be a bit blowy out! Baby, it's hot outside The hot weather can feel uncomfortable for adults, but it's particularly important to keep babies in the shade - as they are less able to sweat to cool down and their skin is very sensitive. So it's worth investing in a stroller or pram with a decent sun visor if you are taking your little one out and about in the sun.  The Joie Mirus Scenic Stroller, &pound120, is an affordable modern stroller which comes with a SPF 50+ sun canopy. (It can also be paired with either the Joie Gemm or Joie Juva Infant Car Seat, to create a travel system, with no adapter needed.)  For playing in the garden or trips to the beach, grab the Halfords Infant Playshade, &pound25. It pops up and down in less than 10 seconds and is made from specially tested material that provides a 50+ UV protection factor. Stay cool in the car  It's fair to say we love most things about summer, but getting into a hot car on a sweltering day isn't one of them. Did you know your air conditioning loses charge every year, making it less efficient and making your car warmer? Halfords now offers a FREE Air Con Check, to check your refrigerant levels and see if they need to be topped up for optimal performance. If they do need topping up, you can purchase air con essentials from store to recharge at home or, you can book in for an air con recharge service and Halfords can take care of it for you. You can also keep out the worst of the heat by investing in a windscreen shield to reflect the sun's glare. The Halfords All Weather Windscreen Shield is just &pound7.99 - and when winter eventually does roll around, you can also use it to protect against the build up of snow and frost.

title: mum who makes cream claims
story: NewsMum who makes cream she claims can help beat cancer battles French probe over “illegal pharmacy”Lesley Hutchings says she had her passport taken away and her bank accounts emptied after being held for four days over allegations of defrauding customers&nbspShareByGrace Macaskill 22:29, 7 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British mum who makes a cream she claims can help beat cancer is battling a French probe accusing her of having an “illegal pharmacy”. Lesley Hutchings says she had her passport taken away and her bank accounts emptied after being held for four days over allegations of defrauding customers. Lesley, 54, was quizzed by French authorities about the cream – which she makes in her barn. The product sells on Facebook for up to &pound40. Police who raided her home in the remote Manche area of Nor&shymandy removed computers and paperwork before sealing up the outbuilding. Officials then took away samples of her MAFactive cream for tests. Lesley – a former accountant who has no formal medical qualifications – says two of the creams have been ruled “satisfactory”, while a third is still being analysed.  Police also quizzed her over her association with David Noakes, who is facing trial over a controversial product called GcMAF – which his company promotes as the “body’s way of becoming cancer free”. Noakes is due in court in the UK later this year on charges of money laundering and manufacturing a medicine without a licence. When the Sunday People visited Lesley at her home, which she hopes to turn into a vegan B&ampB, she insisted her cream does not contain GcMAF, despite the similar name. Lesley told us: “It’s just a name. What difference does it make? It could mean anything – multi-formula cream or whatever.” And she accused the French authorities of victimising her because she once worked with Noakes. Lesley said: “I ran a legitimate business with zero complaints from customers and positive feedback. “I don’t tell people my cream cures cancer. I don’t make any health claims. It’s not illegal to make something amazing – and it’s not illegal for others to tell the world you’ve made something amazing. One Polish woman wrote that she used my cream for tumours that had turned all fungal and said that three weeks later they were gone.  “I don’t even understand why my creams work because science says they shouldn’t work.” Lesley moved to France in 2011 after quitting her job with Noakes, which involved collating customer feedback on GcMAF. She began making her own cream three years ago. Claiming its exact contents are “a trade secret”, she would say only that it contains frankincense and yeast. Her Facebook page promoting the product stated it may help the body “defend itself against pathogens and cancers”. Facebook declined to comment on Lesley using the social networking site to promote her business. She says her business came under scrutiny by French authorities after she posted customer feedback to a private page – including the claims of the woman who said the cream had got rid of skin tumours. Lesley’s premises were raided in February last year – and she is still on bail. She said: “When I got out of prison my passport had been taken away, the banks had been cleared out and I was &pound3,000 overdrawn. “I went from having a wonderful business I loved working in, even though I was doing 70 hours a week, to having it ripped out from under me and being bankrupt – all without a single day in court. This is French justice.  “I don’t feel I’d want to support France any more, a country so abusive to human rights. It’s comparable to Turkey.” On a Facebook page to promote her cream she writes: “This not only ensures healthy skin, but may also help to enable the body to fight off infections, repair and renew its cells and defend itself against pathogens and cancers.” Lesley’s daughter Jasmin raised &pound10,000 from a crowdfunding page to help pay her mum’s legal fees. She said people had described the cream as “almost supernatural”. After her home was raided Lesley was taken to Paris, where a judge questioned her association with Noakes, who claims GcMAF can cure cancer. The so-called miracle drug contains a vitamin D binding protein called glycoprotein, which it is claimed boosts the immune system to help the body fight cancer naturally. Small clinical trials in Japan were dismissed by other experts as they did not take scans of patients’ tumours or analyse their immune systems. But online enthusiasts insist it is a “miracle cure” that is being suppressed by drugs manufacturers. The unlicensed drug is banned in the UK. GcMAF is marketed by Noakes’s Guernsey-based company, Immuno Biotech. The firm’s website claims GcMAF treats a range of conditions, from allergies and asthma to Crohn’s disease, HIV, Parkinson’s disease and autism.

title: new list hand luggage items
story: NewsNew list of hand luggage items set to be BANNED from flights leaving the UKGovernment plans could see make-up, baby powder, coffee and spices banned from hand luggage&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill17:28, 7 JUL 2018Updated22:24, 7 JUL 2018NewsPowders including cosmetics or coffee could be banned from hand luggage as part of a new rules being drawn up by the government (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEveryday items such as make-up, coffee and spices could be banned from hand luggage on all flights leaving the UK, claims a new report. The government is believed to be drawing up a new list of items that must be put in the hold. It comes after Australia, the US and New Zealand introduced similar bans last month. They adopted the new rules after Australian officials were rocked by a foiled plot to blow up an Ethiad flight from Sydney to Abu Dhabi last year. Islamic State sent the sophisticated device from Syria to a terror cell in Sydney hidden in a meat mincer.  A major terror attack may only have been averted when the suitcase was abandoned at check-in, possibly because it was too heavy. The Times reports that the new rules could bring powders under the same restrictions as liquids. All powders would be restricted to 12 ounces or 56 grams and would have to go through further security checks. The rule on liquids were introduced in the wake of 9/11. However, there are fears the new rules could mean even longer lines at airport security. It comes amid worries that the new UK passports, which are blue in colour, will increase queues at border control. The Department of Transport did not comment on The Times' report.  A spokesman said: It is for each country to determine its own security measures based on its own assessments. We work closely with all our international partners to keep aviation security under constant review. Mils Hills, an associate professor in risk, resilience and corporate security at the University of Northampton, said: In itself, these extra restrictions are not going to create a lot of disruption at airport security but it has the potential to feed into general concerns by the public about the safety of flying.

title: new ppi wave pension mis
story: NewsIs this the new PPI? Wave of pension mis-selling could spark windfall for thousandsDuped savers could each pocket £50,000 due to their underperforming pension schemes&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPippa Allen-Kinross11:52, 7 JUL 2018Updated13:52, 7 JUL 2018NewsSenior woman inserting coins into piggybank (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDuped savers could each pocket a &pound50,000 windfall due to their underperforming pension schemes as part of a mammoth SIPP scandal engulfing the UK - which industry experts fear will overtake the current wave of PPI claims. A colossal &pound10 billion worth of badly performing SIPPs - Self Invested Personal Pensions - are believed to have been mis-sold to hundreds of thousands of Brits by unscrupulous financial advisors. Now potential victims are being urged to check if they can reclaim huge portions of their lost cash and the government has set up a special &pound120 million fund to compensate losers so far. A maximum &pound50,000 compensation sum is currently available from the large fund managed by The Financial Service Compensation Scheme and the figure is set to rise by 75 per cent to a &pound85,000 maximum in the next nine months as claims grow. However industry figures such as pension expert Zoe Pearson warn that the true cost of mis-sold pensions is closer to &pound10 billion and will sweep the country like the current phenomenon of PPI claims that has gripped the nation over the past few years.  Read more: Taxed to death: The astonishing amount of income tax people pay decades after leaving work for the last time Miss Pearson, who heads the country’s all female team of claim specialists Pension Claim Consulting Ltd , told : “Thousands upon thousands of people are unaware they’ve been mis-sold SIPPS. Unless you know what to look for it’s difficult to know what a mis-sale is although quite often when people realise they’ve been mis-sold to, they’re too embarrassed to take action. “However, the financial services industry has firm rules, so any mis-sale should be pursued. “Even basic calculations give you an idea of the true scale of this scandal. Average compensation for mis-sales sit at around &pound25,000 for private pensions and &pound50,000 for final salary pensions so the total figure for the mis-sales of SIPPs is going to be around the &pound10bn mark. “In fact if this was brought to the forefront and the government advised people to check the status of their pensions that might even be an underestimation. The government needs to launch an investigation to unearth the true amount.” Labour MP Frank Field has hit out at the SIPP conmen and vowed to bring the industry into line whilst industry experts reveal the true figure of mis-selling is growing at an unprecedented rate and the true loss of mis-selling will run into billions as the number of victims rocket.  Shocking 30.4million Brits face disappointment when they finally get to stop working - the plan to fix it The Financial Ombudsman however are allowed to raise their compensation ceiling and can award up to a further maximum of &pound150,000 for many cases. The SIPP scams involved unscrupulous Financial Advisors preying on savers who were promised massive returns of up to 20 per cent a year only for their savings to be squandered on get rich quick schemes including investing in airport parking, holiday properties and green energy projects. The Financial Conduct Authority revealed one in eight savers think an advisor has mis-sold them a financial product such as a pension. The FCA advise people who think they have been mis-sold a pension to raise a complaint as soon as possible as there are time-limits in place which could affect the outcome of your claim. Their report called the Financial Lives Survey was widely praised by industry experts who believe that the government have underestimated the scale of mis-sold pensions such as SIPPs however the Commons Work and Pensions Committee have demanded tighter safeguards to protect savers. Committee Chairman Frank Field MP said: “I am concerned about the role of SIPPs as platforms that help funnel unwitting clients’ pension savings into dodgy and inappropriate investments. SIPPs are happy to skim off their fee on the way but there are serious questions about their commitment to due diligence and consumer protection. “When an unscrupulous financial advisor channels a victim’s money through a SIPP into an investment that then collapses, it is not enough for the SIPP provider to shrug their shoulders and say ‘caveat emptor’. “I will be writing to the FCA to ask what they are doing to ensure SIPPS are not acting as handmaidens to the pension-snatchers.”

title: pippa middleton reveals one thing
story: NewsPippa Middleton reveals the one thing she's refusing to give up during her pregnancyPippa Middleton is expecting her first child with husband James Matthews&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer17:36, 6 JUL 2018NewsPippa is pregnant with her first child (Image: Rex)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen women find out they're pregnant, their lives change forever. Even though they're still months away from meeting their baby, the changes to their day-to-day life start immediately. There's a whole host of foods they can no longer eat, they can't drink and they will sometimes have to give up the hobbies they love. But there's one thing Pippa Middleton, who is expecting her first child with husband James Matthews, is refusing to give up despite that growing baby bump.   Writing in her column for Waitrose Weekend , the Duchess of Cambridge's little sister, 34, explains why she is still playing tennis.  She said: I've been a tennis fan since childhood, as player and spectator, and have been keen to continue playing safely throughout pregnancy. Take Serena Williams – she famously proved that women can play a high level of tennis from two months (when she won the 2017 Australian Open) up to eight months. Few of us can relate to this elite excellence, but if you're a healthy, well-trained player with an uncomplicated pregnancy there's no reason why you can't continue a good level of tennis.  It is believed Pippa is due in October. And it's not just playing which Pippa enjoys, and she's a regular at Wimbledon. She was in the crowds for day four of this year's competition with her brother James.

title: story one time double glazing
story: NewsThe story of the one time double-glazing salesman who became an international drugs kingpinMartin Evans was arrested in South Africa after years on the run and was sentenced to 24 years in a high security prison&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJason Evans12:08, 8 JUL 2018Updated12:09, 8 JUL 2018NewsMartin Evans tending to his ostriches (Image: Dragon News and Picture Agency)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAt the height of the mad cow disease scare, from the confines of his prison cell, former young businessman of the year Martin Evans came up with an audacious ostrich-meat scam which robbed some pensioners of their life savings.  Before he became a drugs kingpin, smuggling millions of pounds worth of cocaine and ecstasy pills into the UK, Evans set up his bizarre scam with his wife.   It was while he was serving time for a deception conviction, stemming from his years running his double-glazing business, that he dreamt up the scam . During the BSE scare ostrich meat was seen by many as a low-fat and safe alternative to beef and lamb.   He saw it as an opportunity to make money and shortly after his release from prison, he launched an ostrich farm and breeding-business in Dunvant near Swansea, Wales Online reports.   The Ostrich Centre was advertised in national newspapers with the slogan Ostrich Nest Egg and offered investors the chance to buy an ostrich, promising them big returns of 70 per cent or more on their investment. The simple idea won the backing of more than 100 people, including many pensioners, who were tricked into investing a total of &pound875,000 in the fledging company. While the ostriches themselves were real, Evans was selling each bird several times over to different investors and pocketing the cash from the people he duped. The cash was funnelled off into off-shore bank accounts in Jersey and the Bahamas. Between February and July 1996 investors pumped hundreds of thousands of pounds into the venture, taken-in by Evans' sales patter. But just six months after being launched, the company was declared insolvent - though not before &pound329,000 had been stolen from investors. When the business was revealed as a scam, a number of angry investors descended on Bevexe Fawr Farm in Dunvant and seized birds to try to recoup some of their money. Auditors nothing in the firm's bank account - save for a &pound440 overdraft. A police investigation was launched, and the Evanses were subsequently charged with fraud and theft. From running a successful double-glazing business he ended up as a Mr Big of the drugs world, running a gang of cocaine smugglers while living the high-life in a luxury apartment in Marbella. Some of those who knew him - and some of those who were taken in by him - describe him as charming. He was certainly an accomplished liar. Evans grew up in Pontarddulais, and attended Ysgol Gyfun Ystalyfera in the Swansea Valley. He was said to have left school with few qualifications.  After dabbling with DJing, he ran a video rental shop but his first taste of success came when he launched a double-glazing firm in Neath . Within 18 months the firm was employing 20 people, and in 1987 he scooped the Welsh Young Businessperson of the Year title. Business was good, and Evans and his wife Esther began to enjoy the trapping of success, including Mercedes cars with personalised number plates. So far, it seemed, so good. But the double-glazing business eventually folded, and in 1994 Evans was convicted of obtaining property by deception and sentenced to 15 months in prison. Evans saw an opportunity to make money. And the story may well have ended there, as just another scheme that indeed proved too good to be true. But just as the trial was about to start in 2000, Martin Evans faxed Swansea Crown Court to say he would not be attending - in fact the 38-year-old had skipped the country and run away to Spain with his mistress. His wife was left to face the charges alone. The money in the offshore accounts had also vanished, meaning investors lost everything - apart from those who had indulged in a spot of unofficial Swansea ostrich wrangling. The case against Mrs Evans, who is originally from Brynamman , went ahead in her husband's absence - she was found guilty of four charges of theft and one of fraudulent trading, and given a two-year suspended prison sentence. Judge Michael Burr told the court he had no doubt the ostrich farm had been a scam from the very beginning. He said: I am satisfied that the whole ostrich farm was set up from the beginning as a dishonest means of depriving investors of their money.  The judge told Mrs Evans that he did not believe she was the innocent dupe she had pretended to be, but he accepted that she had been manipulated by her husband. As for the on-the-run Evans, after video rentals, double glazing, and ostrich farming fraud, he became involved in a new and highly lucrative kind of business - international drug dealing. From a hideaway in Spain he masterminded a multi-million-pound drugs and money laundering operation, which smuggled huge quantities of cocaine and ecstasy from mainland Europe into Britain. Evans reaped an estimated &pound9million leading a gang of couriers who trafficked the drugs from Holland and Spain to the UK - the money was laundered through a bureau de change next door to the world-famous Harrods store in London. Gang members would carry cocaine into Britain in multiples of one kilo packets, with upwards of 100,000 ecstasy tablets also being carried on each trip. It was a lucrative enterprise. But unbeknown to the gang, police had them under surveillance following a tip-off about the large sums of money they were changing into different currencies. A complex undercover operation saw officers following the couriers as they went about the business, and police even managed to bug the car of Evans' second-in-command, former soldier Paul Jeffreys from Llanelli. In October 2001, officers swooped on the gang as Jeffreys and his girlfriend, Lucy Kift, handed over &pound145,000 in Dutch guilders to another gang member at a motorway service station near Reading. As officers moved-in, the bug in Jeffreys' car picked him up saying I have had it. In Jeffreys' car police found another &pound284,000 worth of guilders and Spanish pesetas. Other members of the gang were then arrested as their operation was dismantled. Evans, however, slipped through the net and remained at large. But his time as a fugitive - his first time as a fugitive, that is - would be short-lived.  Later that year border staff New York's JKF airport became suspicious of a man who arrived in the country with a passport in the name of Paul Kelly - it was a time of heightened security in the wake of the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Kelly, it turned out, was one of the alias being used by Evans. The passport proved to be a fake, Interpol were alerted, Evans was arrested, and he was deported to France - where he would spend the next three years in jail before being extradited to Britain to stand trial. While he was in prison in Paris, eight other members of his gang were jailed for a total of 70 years at Swansea Crown Court, with Jeffreys receiving 16 years for trafficking. Judge John Diehl attacked the gang's ugly, repulsive trade in human misery which had blighted communities across South Wales. One member of the gang, Richard Hughes, of Llansamlet, Swansea, was found to have a loaded Walther handgun in the boot of his car. He was jailed for 10 years. Alan Thomas from Pontardawe was sentenced to seven years, and Steven Summers, from Llanelli, to six years. Three men from Folkestone were also jailed - Jason Flisher got 14 years, Freddy Lawrence 11 years, and Leslie West three years. Kift was jailed for three years - the court heard the 22-year-old had gained little from the operation apart from sorrow. When Evans eventually appeared at Swansea Crown Court it emerged he had been involved in yet another alleged scam, this time involving healthy chocolate bars - but the prosecution said it was not in the public interest to pursue the charges given the sentence the defendant was already facing for the drug conspiracy offences.  Evans was sentenced to a total of 24 years in prison for drugs trafficking and the Ostrich farm scam, and hit with a &pound4.8million confiscation order to reclaim his ill-gotten gains. The court heard that as well as properties in Swansea the defendant had a &pound2million luxury villa in Marbella - complete with a swimming pool and staff - and a penthouse in Miami's South Beach near Trump Towers. He also bank accounts in Latvia, Antigua, Switzerland, Dominica, and the UK. Simon Flowers, Wales branch commander at the National Crime Agency (NCA), described Evans at the time as a Mr Big. He said: Evans was in control of the Wales market. He was the number one drug importer into Wales in and around that time. No two ways about it. He would also have had significant influence on the rest of UK as well. Evans' 24 year sentence was later reduced to 21 years on appeal. By 2011 Evans was in Erlestoke open prison in Wiltshire, and was being prepared for early release the following year - as part of the arrangements to facilitate his return to the community he was granted re-settlement visits back to Swansea. On one of these trips he took the chance to flee the authorities once more, and again skipped the country. His second period on the run would last much longer that his first. The NCA launched an international manhunt to find him, and put him on the list of the 11 most-wanted British fugitives. It is believed Evans first fled to Northern Cyprus - which had no extradition treaty with Britain - but given Evans' international connections the search operation included law enforcement agencies across Europe, the Caribbean, and America. It took three years to find the elusive Evans.

title: suspected new banksy artwork appears
story: NewsSuspected new Banksy artwork appears in Birmingham streetThe elusive artist is famous for his provocative graffiti pieces appearing suddenly in public locations&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTony LarnerPippa Allen-Kinross09:54, 8 JUL 2018NewsMystery surrounds Banksy's real identity (Image: Bristol Post WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A stunning artwork which has suddenly appeared on a wall in Birmingham is thought to be the latest piece from elusive graffiti artist Banksy .  The image, which appeared in Digbeth, shows a little girl sat on the ground in dark clothes and frowning, while holding a red heart-shaped balloon with the word 'tame' written on it. It has been painted on a wall in the heavily graffitied Floodgate Street, in Birmingham's 'creative quarter'.  Birmingham Live reported that one local who photographed the image on his way to work said: This has only just been painted. I think it is a Banksy as the pure level of detail in the work speaks volumes. The Custard Factory, a nearby independent shopping centre and with creative workspaces, posted a photograph of the new artwork on Instagram with the caption 'Is this who we think it is?!' Banksy, a graffiti artist, political activist and film director, has made headlines across the world for his iconic and often controversial pieces for over a decade. Las year rapper Goldie hinted at the artist's true identity, during an interview with spoken word poet Scroobius Pip, for his Distraction Pieces podcast.  The drum and bass legend was being interviewed for the podcast when he referred to the elusive artist as 'Robert .  It is thought to be confirmation that Banksy is his friend Robert Del Naja - a member of Massive Attack. Del Naja - known as 3D - is a pal of the hip hop star and they were both graffiti artists in the same circles in the late 1980s. In the podcast Goldie is ranting about how the art industry is cashing in on Banksy. He says: Give me a bubble letter and put it on a t-shirt and write 'Banksy' on it and we're sorted. We can sell it now. No disrespect to Robert, I think he is a brilliant artist.

title: thrifty shoppers score cheap out
story: NewsThrifty shoppers score cheap out-of-date food delivered to save cash – and cut wasteThousands of products – including pasta, biscuits, crisps and cake bars – past their “best before” dates are being snapped up at bargain prices&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByStephen Hayward21:48, 7 JUL 2018Updated09:11, 8 JUL 2018NewsThe new service is operated by Fultons Foods, which hopes it will reduce the amount of perfectly usable produce that gets binned (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThrifty shoppers are getting cheap out-of-date food delivered to save cash – and cut waste. Thousands of products – including pasta, biscuits, crisps and cake bars – past their “best before” dates are being snapped up at bargain prices. The new service is operated by Fultons Foods, which hopes it will reduce the amount of perfectly usable produce that gets binned. An astonishing seven million tonnes of food is thrown away in the UK every year, of which three-&shyquarters, or five million tonnes, could still have been safely eaten. Family-run Fultons, which is based in Barnsley, South Yorks, operates 100 stores in the Midlands and North. It sells surplus stock direct from manufacturers at “significantly” lower prices than supermarkets.  The firm’s Karen Gunter said: “An increasing number of UK householders are saving hundreds of pounds by taking advantage of the reality of best before dates. These products are perfectly fine to eat.” “Best before” is a manufacturer’s indication that an item may not be as good quality, but it is not unsafe. Bargains include roast chicken and pasta Mug Shot down from 84p to 29p, Galaxy cake bars down from &pound1 to 79p, bottles of 7 Up lemonade down from &pound1.10 to 59p, and Golden Wonder salt and vinegar crisps from 79p to 50p.  Deliveries, which are made by couriers, are free for groceries costing &pound30 or over. Online retailer Approved Food runs a similar scheme offering 2,000 items near or past “best before” dates. It claims regular customers can save &pound70 on their monthly shop compared to high street prices. The firm’s biggest-selling items include tinned tomatoes and pasta.
